frameDefinitions: This frame consists of LUs which denote a Theme ceasing motion.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
A Guest stays for a time at a Location, which is not his or her permanent residence, for some Duration.
A Judge refrains from imposing, or demanding a punishment for an Evaluee who has committed an Offense.
These are words relating to filling containers and covering areas with some thing, things or substance, the Theme.
A Traveller leaves from or dismounts a Vehicle.
frameExamples: Peter <t>stopped</t> immediately and span to see Aeryn frozen where she stood.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
I usually <t>stay</t> with my aunt at her summer house when I go to Seville.
Lionel Hutz <t>coated</t> the wall with paint.
listRoleDefinitions: This role identifies <fen>Theme</fen> whose motion ceases.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Theme</fen> stops.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Theme</fen>'s motion stops.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
The <fen>Guest</fen> remains for a relatively short period of time in the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Location</fen> where the <fen>Guest</fen> spends a short amount of time.
The length of time that the <fen>Guest</fen> remains at the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Host</fen> is living at the <fen>Location</fen> on a permanent basis, and is allowing the <fen>Guest</fen> to stay there.
The time at which the temporary stay takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates the larger physical setting of the temporary stay.
The <fen>Judge</fen> holds the <fen>Evaluee</fen> responsible for the <fen>Offense</fen>.
The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is subject to the judgment of the <fen>Judge</fen> for having committed the <fen>Offense</fen>.
The <fen>Offense</fen> is the illicit or unpleasant act committed by the <fen>Evaluee</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the actor who instigates the filling.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the physical object or substance which changes location.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the area or container being filled. Goal is generally the NP Object in this frame.
An event which brings about the filling of the <fen>Goal</fen>.
When the filling occurs.
Where the filling takes place.
The <fen>Traveller</fen> is the entity which disembarks from the <fen>Vehicle</fen>.
The <fen>Vehicle</fen> is the means of conveyance that the <fen>Traveller</fen> disembarks from.
When the disembarking of the <fen>Vehicle</fen> takes place.
The location in which the <fen>Traveller</fen> disembarks from the <fen>Vehicle</fen>.
listRoleExamples: When the kitty was standing beside the slayer's pillow, <fex>she</fex> stopped to make sure everything was quiet
John stopped <fex>suddenly</fex>, whirled around and spread out his arms
She stopped <fex>on the threshold</fex> with a sinking heart
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
Originally, <fex>we</fex> planned on rooming with our relatives in Reno.
Originally we planned on staying <fex>at the Hilton</fex>.
My wife and have just returned from a <fex>two day</fex> stay at Ocean Key.
You should avoid staying <fex>with old college buddies</fex> when on business trips.
He'll be lodging here <fex>next month</fex>.
<fex>In London</fex>, I stayed at a hotel.
God forgives <fex>repentant sinners</fex>.
Won't you forgive me <fex>for keeping it a secret</fex>?
Rev. Lovejoy carefully brushed the rolls <fex>with butter</fex>.
<fex>We</fex> got off at the wrong bus stop.
The victim stopped the tractor and dismounted <fex>from it</fex>.
<fex>Yesterday</fex>, we alighted onto this tiny hilly island, site of a Singaporean October festival.
